abstract.p: Daniel Okrent letter about June article on concert halls says one of most appealing things about great music is that it belongs to all of us (S)

block.p: Lawrence Kramer is on to something when he suggests that a vibrant concert hall could have much in common with an excellent art museum. But he misses the mark when he laments the lack of a ''classical music equivalent of the contemporary-art market.'' The only reason a contemporary-art market exists is that art can be owned, and collectors have a pecuniary interest in escalating prices. One of the most appealing things about great music is that it belongs to all of us.
The writer is a former public editor of The New York Times.
